channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Trump, Military Strike in Iran Could Serve Symbolic Purpose
item.description: Some officials in the Trump administration hope an attack would force Iran to give up its nuclear enrichment program. Others have doubts.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: American fighter jets on the aircraft carrier Gerald R. Ford off the coast of Greece. The U.S. military is amassing firepower in the region near Iran.

item.title: A Deal or War? Crucial Talks to Begin Between U.S. and Iran
item.description: President Trump has kept up a steady drumbeat of threats and built up U.S. troops in the region. Iran’s task is to give him a win but also preserve some semblance of nuclear enrichment.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A large billboard depicting missiles in Tehran in 2024. While nuclear enrichment is being discussed this week, Iran’s missile program is not currently on the table.

item.title: Trump’s Push for Election Power Raises Fears He Will ‘Subvert’ Midterms
item.description: The president appears to be undermining Americans’ faith in the outcome, at a moment when Republicans face an uphill climb to keep control of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: During his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Trump suggested that “it should be my third term” and falsely declared that the “only way” that Democrats “can get elected is to cheat.”

item.title: Casey Means, Surgeon General Nominee, Sidesteps Questions on Vaccines at Senate Hearing
item.description: Dr. Casey Means, a wellness influencer, author and supporter of Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., said that “anti-vaccine rhetoric has never been part” of her message.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Alex Kent for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Our nation is angry, exhausted and hurting from preventable diseases,” Dr. Casey Means told the Senate Health Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: Patel Fires F.B.I. Personnel Tied to Inquiry Into Trump and Classified Records
item.description: The firings are part of a rolling barrage of retribution aimed at those who worked on the two federal prosecutions of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Devlin Barrett
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.B.I. building in Washington, D.C. The firings came hours after Kash Patel, the F.B.I. director, said that as part of the documents inquiry, the bureau had subpoenaed phone metadata for himself and Susie Wiles, currently the White House chief of staff.

item.title: Epstein Files Are Missing Records About Woman Who Made Claim Against Trump
item.description: Documents released by the Justice Department briefly mention a woman’s unverified accusation that Donald J. Trump assaulted her in the 1980s, when she was a minor. But several memos related to her account are not in the files.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Michael Gold
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: When the Justice Department made files public late last month, officials said it included all material sent by the public to the F.B.I.

item.title: With Epstein Deposition, Hillary Clinton Is Again Answering for Bill Clinton’s Actions
item.description: The former first lady, senator and secretary of state had no dealings with Jeffrey Epstein but is once again under pressure to answer for the actions and relationships of her husband.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton with President Bill Clinton in December 1998, after he was impeached by the House of Representatives.

item.title: Larry Summers Will Resign From Harvard After Jeffrey Epstein Revelations
item.description: Mr. Summers, former president of the school, had stepped back from teaching after documents showed a closer relationship to Jeffrey Epstein than previously known. He will leave at the end of the academic year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawrence Summers discussed relationships with Jeffrey Epstein in a correspondence that lasted for years, documents show.

item.title: Former Nebraska Sen. Bob Kerrey Resigns From Monolith Amid Epstein Emails
item.description: Mr. Kerrey has left his role as chairman of the company, Monolith, after Justice Department documents showed he had met and corresponded with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:description: Bob Kerrey speaking in Omaha in 2012.

item.title: Super-Agers’ Brains Have a Special Ability, New Study Suggests
item.description: The findings may help explain why this group has such exceptional memory.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith

item.title: President Emmanuel Macron’s Cultural Legacy At Risk After Louvre Chief Resigns
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron has championed a refurbishment of the museum, but the fallout from a sensational heist has put his plans at risk.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron giving a speech last year at the Louvre, in front of the Mona Lisa.

item.title: Nvidia’s Quarterly Profit Hits $43 Billion on Strong A.I. Chip Sales
item.description: Total profit for the fiscal year was $120 billion, the company said. Three years ago, it was just $4.4 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia, led by Jensen Huang, above, said quarterly revenue from its chips for A.I. data centers had risen 71 percent to $61.7 billion.

item.title: F.B.I. Raids Home and Office of L.A.U.S.D. Chief Alberto Carvalho
item.description: The investigation appears to be related to a $6 million contract the district had with a tech start-up whose staff had ties to the superintendent, Alberto Carvalho.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Dana Goldstein and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.B.I. raided the home of Alberto M. Carvalho, superintendent of the Los Angeles Unified School District, and the district offices on Wednesday.

item.title: One Nation, an Anti-Immigration Party in Australia, Rises in Polls After Bondi Massacre
item.description: The foreign roots of the men accused of killing 15 at a Jewish event have helped make Pauline Hanson and her One Nation party more palatable for some Australians.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Darren England/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Pauline Hanson, the leader of the One Nation party, at a rally in Brisbane, Australia, last month. She has long argued that Australia needs to curb what she calls “mass migration.”

item.title: Inside Tapalpa, the Town in Mexico Where El Mencho Made His Last Stand
item.description: Times reporters visiting Tapalpa found a serene town in shock after Sunday’s raid on its outskirts left dozens dead and people fleeing. And, surprisingly, no police or military presence where the battle took place.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Tapalpa, in Jalisco state, Mexico, is a stronghold of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of a Notorious Florida Nudist Colony
item.description: The owners have put a 67-year-old nudist colony on the market, hoping a new steward can help it shed its troubled past.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.category: Lake Como Family Nudist Resort (Lutz, Fla)
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Dragos Lemnei/The New York Times
item.media:description: In its heyday, the Florida Naturist Park had an eclectic following.

item.title: U.S. Will Offer Embassy Services in a West Bank Settlement for the First Time
item.description: Palestinians and Israelis on the right and left all say that the move is a step toward legitimizing the Israeli settlements, which most of the world considers illegal.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: The Israeli settlement of Efrat in the Israeli-occupied West Bank in 2020. The U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem says it will provide passport assistance in Efrat on Friday.

item.title: Everyone Hates This Highway. What’s the Best Way to Fix It?
item.description: Community groups are opposing proposals to expand the decades-old Cross Bronx Expressway in favor of more limited repairs and improvements to local streets.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.media:credit: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is preparing to announce a plan for a $900 million overhaul of a one-mile elevated section of the aging Cross Bronx Expressway.

item.title: 45 Years After Failed Coup, Spain Declassifies Files About Why It Failed
item.description: Ending more than four decades of conjecture, the Spanish government moved to publish documents from a long-secret investigation of a failed 1981 coup.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Antonio Tejero Molina, with a pistol in his hand, attempting a coup at the Spanish Parliament on Feb. 23, 1981.

item.title: Antonio Tejero Molina, 93, Dies; Spanish Colonel Led Failed Coup
item.description: He held Spain’s Parliament hostage for 18 hours on Feb. 23, 1981, before surrendering after it became clear that he had little support from the country’s armed forces.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: Antonio Tejero Molina on Feb. 23, 1981, the day he led a takeover of the Parliament in Spain as part of an attempted coup.

item.title: Japan Is Redefining Its Place in the World
item.description: Sanae Takaichi’s political rise presages a stronger Japan that could reshape the strategic balance in Asia and help deter Chinese aggression.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Walker

item.title: Trump’s State of the Union Was a Win for Democrats
item.description: Ezra Klein and Aaron Retica react to Trump’s 2026 State of the Union speech.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein, Aaron Retica, Claire Gordon and Marie Cascione
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: North Korea’s ​Kim Jong-un Hints at Improving U.S. Relations — With Caveats
item.description: ​ The North Korean leader said that his country can get along well with the United States as long as Washington accepts it as a nuclear weapons state.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A news broadcast in Seoul on Thursday showing footage of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, speaking at the ruling Workers’ Party congress.

item.title: The Gorton and Denton By-Election Comes at a Bad Time for Keir Starmer
item.description: A parliamentary by-election in Gorton and Denton, outside Manchester, will test support for Britain’s prime minister at a moment of intense political pressure.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at a Labour campaign event on Monday ahead of the Gorton and Denton by-election in Manchester, England.

item.title: Bird Flu Strikes California Elephant Seals for the First Time
item.description: Thirty seals, primarily weaned pups, have died since late last week, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Elephant seals at Año Nuevo State Park in Pescadero, Calif., last month.

item.title: Hong Kong Court Overturns Jimmy Lai’s Fraud Conviction, in Rare Win
item.description: Mr. Lai was sentenced on Feb. 9. Weeks later, a court quashed a separate fraud conviction against him, a ruling that did not shorten his imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and David Pierson
item.media:description: Mr. Lai was one of the first targets of the national security law.
